headline.main: Behind New York's Smoking Ban, the Tenacity of Two Legislators

docs.abstract: Albany insiders say it was perseverance of Assemblyman Alexander B Grannis, Manhattan Democrat, and Sen Charles J Fuschillo Jr, Long Island Republican, that led to enactment of landmark legislation that bans smoking in nearly all workplaces in New York State; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: When Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis proposed his first antismoking bill a quarter-century ago, many of the lawmakers here laughed it off. Some blew smoke in his face, literally. But now Mr. Grannis is the one smiling, after the Legislature enacted landmark legislation last week that bans smoking in nearly all workplaces, including restaurants and bars, in the state. Gov. George E. Pataki immediately signed the bill, allowing it to take effect in late July.

headline.main: Success Stories Abound in Efforts to Prevent and Control Cancer

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses differences in cancer tests, treatments and outcomes since American Cancer Society published first annual study Cancer Facts and Figures 50 years ago; hlds that many types of cancers can now be treated effectively if detected early; contends that statistics prove that routine medical exams and self exams save lives; asserts that smoking causes more cancers than any other single factor and lung cancer is leading cause of death for men and women; notes that childhood cancer deaths have plummeted from 3,200 children in 1953 to estimated 1,500 in 2003 due mainly to innovative treatment therapies; graph (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Anyone who has recently lost a loved one to cancer may be inclined to think that little progress has been made in conquering this complex disease. That would be very wrong. The advances in the last 50 years in understanding the causes of cancer and in detecting and treating it have turned many once fatal cancers into curable and, sometimes, preventable diseases.
